I.INTRODUCTION
1. The SAL-Social Sectors -Loan 7137 inthe amount of US$151,520,000 was approved by the Board of Directors on August 8, 2002. The first tranche of US$101,520,000 (including the front- endfee) was released on August 9,2002. The second tranche amounts to US$50 million. The SSAL-National Mortgage Bank (BHU) -Loan 7138 inthe amount of US$151,520,000 was approved by the Board of Directors on August 8, 2002. The first tranche of US$101,520,000 (including the front-end fee) was released on August 9,2002. The second tranche amounts to US$50 million.
2. The objectives of the SAL and SSAL at the time of the acute banlung and economic crisis in July 2002 were to contribute to fiscal adjustment, reform the National Mortgage Bank (BHU), protect social programs, improve the efficiency of social expenditures and reform the unemployment insurance regime. The program was part of a concerted effort with the InternationalMonetary Fund(IMF)and the Inter-AmericanDevelopment Bank (IADB) to support Uruguay's efforts to withstand the impact of strong external shocks, address domestic weaknesses and set the stage for sustainable growth over the medium and long term. As a result of tight fiscal, monetary and financial sector policies andreforms, Uruguay was able to reverse the downwardtrend inbank deposits, freely float its exchange rate without jeopardizing price stability, andreduce sovereign risk premia to manageable levels. After contracting sharply in 2002, the economy recovered in2003 and i s projectedto grow at least 9% in 2004.
3. The success with which Uruguay was able to weather the economic crisis owes much to the Government's prompt and purposeful responseto events as they unfolded, as well as to the support for adjustment provided by the opposition. The Government deserves credit for carrying out policy adjustments through existing institutionalchannels, respecting contracts, and avoiding interrupting normal government procedures. The Government was able to manage proactively the social situation and to mobilize an already well established and effective social safety net to mitigate the sizable increase inpoverty (from 11.7% in 2001 to 21% of households in2003) and unemployment (which peaked at 19.8% inthe last quarter of 2002); unemployment has subsequently dropped by one-third (to around 13% inthe second quarter of 2004).
4. With regard to the SAL, all specific conditions except one (condition 9 regarding enactment of a new unemployment insurance law) have been satisfactorily achieved. Political opposition impeded condition 9 from being achieved. However, improvedenforcement of existing legislation has permitted the Government to reduce significantly extensions of unemployment insurance benefits beyond the initial eligibility period which was a key objective of the proposed legislation.  - 2 -
5. With regard to the SSAL, all eight specific conditions except one (condition 6 regarding implementation of an integrated information system) have been satisfactorily achieved. The delay in implementingthe information system can be in part explained by the strategic approach pursuedby Government of passing key legislation through Congress (e.g., new BHUCharter) before beginning the effective restructuring of the bank; and inpart by the appointment of a more pro-reform boardin October 2003. Since then, the Uruguayan Government has demonstrated a clear intention and pragmatic steps regarding implementationof an integrated information system for BHU. The Government i s expected to award a contract for the new information system in October 2004 with support from the World Bank's Technical Assistance Loan (TAL) 45980-UR. However, the implementationprocess i s expected to take at least another eight months; it i s for this reason that the Government has requested a waiver.
6. Inview of the overall performance, progress with the implementationof the program as described inthe Letter of DevelopmentPolicy, and compliance with most of the specific conditions agreedin Schedule 3 to the Loan Agreements, the granting of two waivers (out of 18 conditions) as requested by the Borrower i s recommended on a no-objectionbasis for release of the second tranche of the Loans 7137 and 7138. The basis for the evaluation of Borrower performance and the recommended waivers i s set out below.

9. Progressachievedbv the Borrowerincarryingout the Program-condition (i).The Government's program addressedthe key structural problems facing the country as identifiedin  - 3 -
the LDPby: (a) achievingan unprecedented fiscal turnaround as the primary fiscal deficit of 1.2% of GDP was turned into a 2.8% surplus in 2003 and a projected 3.6% in 2004; (b) adopting a floating exchange rate regime and a monetary base-targeting regime to simultaneously address issues of external competitiveness and price stability; (c) aggressively restructuringthe largest public banks, liquidating weak domestic privatebanks and strengthening prudential regulation and supervision; and (d) increasing private sector participationintelecommunications, transport and gas, and, to a more limited extent, progressing inthe development of a regulatory framework conducive to competition and increased private sector participationinelectricity. Inaddition, the Government was able to successfully restructure sovereign debt with private bondholders, significantly improving the time profile of debt amortizations without increasing interest rates above pre-crisis levels.
10. The following specific actions described in the LDP were fulfilled:
The Government submitted to Congress comprehensive tax packages that included elimination of several low-yielding taxes and broadening the value added tax (VAT) base. Timing for congressional approval remains uncertain inview of the upcoming elections. However, despite the sharp economic contraction in 2002 and the first half of 2003, tax revenue during 2003 rose faster than inflation and tax buoyancy continued in 2004. Significant efforts to modernize the Tax Administration Department (DGI) and reduce evasion and a strong economic recovery (output growth of 12.6% was achieved in the first half) were conducive to this outcome.
0 The Government was able to contain real public expenditures including wages and pensions during the second half of 2002. During2003, the share of public wages in GDP declined further from 6.9% to 6.2% and the share of social security benefits declined from 16.3% to 13.7%.
The Government has made progress in gradually promoting competition between public and private service providers. A number of road and port concessions have been granted and private investors were engaged in the construction of two new ports. The main airport was given inconcession to an international firm during 2003. In telecommunications, a new cellular competitor (the third) recently entered the market and important developments in data transmission have materialized. The Government has established an independent multi-sector regulator covering water, electricity, gas, oil and sanitation (URSEA) and a telecommunications regulator (URSEC). A gas distribution system has been concessioned and the monopoly on gas imports has been eliminated. A privately financed gas pipeline from Argentina was concluded and the distribution network i s being expanded. Partial progress has been made inequalizing tax treatment between public and private sector providers, e.g., public enterprises in manufacturing now have the same treatment as private firms for social security contributions. Also, restrictions on public enterprises to contract publicity on public radio have been reduced.
The Government has fulfilled a promise to revise productivity sharingclauses for public enterprise employees reducing this expensein aggregate by at least 50% in real terms.  - 4 -
0 The Government has phased out specific rights on imports of goods, eliminated temporary import tariffs imposedin 1998,lowered tariffs on imports of capital goods to either 0% or 2%, and to 2% on all telecom and informatics goods (these measures required a special MERCOSUR exemption from the common external tariff).
On social security, the Government submittedto Congress comprehensive packagesfor reform of the police and military special pension regimes.
11.Progress with the implementationof the Programhasbeen satisfactory to the Bank andthe resulting macroeconomic performance i s better than anticipated. The LDP envisaged average growth of 3-4% in 2003-05, whereas projected average growth over 2003-04 i s now in the 5 6 % range. There have been some deviations as Congress didnot validate several Government initiatives like the comprehensive tax packages sent in December 2002 and June 2003 and the Government could not obtain sufficient political support to send other legislation to Congress, e.g., changes to unemployment insurance. However, the overall progress inpolicy reform has been highly satisfactory, more than compensating the deviations with major strengths inthe fiscal, financial, monetary and social areas. Most important, the programhas been highly successful inover-achieving fiscal and output targets and inreversing the massive run on bank deposits. Approximately two-thirds of resident deposits that fled the system have already returned and the banks have regained high liquidity levels.
12. Satisfactorv Macroeconomic Policv Framework -condition Cii).Basedonpolicyactions, reforms and overall performance, the macroeconomic policy framework i s satisfactory to the Bank.
13. Uruguay's macroeconomic performance over 2003-2004 has reacted favorably to adjustment and reforms inresponse to the 2002 crisis. Output increased 2.5% in2003 and i s expected to grow 9% in2004, with inflation inthe 10% range despite hefty increases in tariffs to reflect higher international energy prices. Internationalreserves have risen to around 20% of GDP-- excluding commercial banks' own reserves--while banking stability has been regained. Underlyingthis performance are sound fiscal accounts. Fiscal adjustment has been achieved through a combination of expenditure restraint and more recently tax buoyancy. State enterprises also contributedto the large primary surpluses. Sovereign debt with private creditors was successfully restructured inMay 2003, with the maturity of bonds being lengthened at least 5 years at (or below) pre-crisis interest rates.
14. The biggest challenge for Uruguayi s to create conditions for fast and sustainable growth; a Bank report on Uruguay's sources of growth i s underway with extensive consultation with the Government, representatives of the political parties and the private sector. While performance will remain dependent on regional and internationaldevelopments, Uruguay i s inrelatively good shape to take advantage of the very strong recovery underway. The country's dependenceon MERCOSUR for its export markets has diminished significantly over 2002-03 from around 60% to under 30% of Uruguay's exports. The new Government will receive a more solvent financial system (non-performing loans declined from 26% inlate 2002 to 15% inJune 2004 - provisions inJune covered 87% of non-performing loans), a sizable primary fiscal surplus andrenewed  - 5 -
political support to embark on new reforms necessary to support fast and sustained growth over the rest of the decade.
15. Against the favorable background of economic recovery, the public debt i s large and sustainability remains critically dependent on Uruguay's ability to deepen current fiscal efforts, particularly after a new government takes over inMarch 2005. Implementationof the structural reform agenda has slowed duringthe runup to the elections inOctober 2004. However, all the major parties have re-affirmedtheir commitment to honor debt obligations and to maintain fiscal discipline. Progress on the de-monopolization of energy infrastructure has suffered a setback partly for political reasons, though it continues to advance well intransport, telecommunications and gas. The IMFcompleted the fifth review of the Stand-By Agreement in September 2004 with a positive evaluation of fiscal and monetary policies as well as the restructuringof public banks. Authorities have agreedto maintain a larger surplus than the 3.4% target if revenue exceeds programprojections in2004.

iii) BHU'sprincipalfutureactivitywillbeassetsecuritization. Article2ofthenewlaw allows BHUto transfer mortgages or cash-flows associated with them to investment funds.
iv) New mortgages (excluding those issued to place property/assets already belongingto the bank) will not exceed an established ceiling equivalent to an aggregate amount of US$50 million. Article 3 of the new law specifies that new mortgages cannot exceed the lesser of UI 1,500 million (UI- Inflation IndexedUnits) or 75% of the bank's capital (based on central bank accounting principles). The former amounted to US$56 million inAugust 2002 slightly higher than the US$50 million ceiling mentioned in the LDP. However, the condition states that the law should "substantially" reflect the LDPAnnex. For a bank with assets of US$1,345 million, a discrepancy of US$6 million or 0.45% i s considered minor.
V I BHUwill adopt amechanism to reduce the capture of bank deposits other than from the system of ahorroprevio (article 5).
vi) BHUwill cancel all obligations throughissue of securities, bonds or transferable assets after 15 years (article 6).
vii) The Executive i s authorized to constitute a guarantee fund using 1% of the personal income tax to partially guarantee non-performing mortgages. Article 7 of Law 17596 further restricts the guarantee to social housing and establishes a 20% limit per loan and a 20% limit of loans i.e. a 4% total limit which i s inline with the original 5% requirement.  - 1 3 -
viii) Article 143 of the Billto Congress requiredthat BHUagree with the Executive on a plan to reduce staff, operational expenses and investments 60 days following the approval of the proposed law. This recommendation has not been enacted inLaw 17596. However, BHUand the Executive have indeed complied with the objectives since the reduction was done anyway, amounting to 35% of expenses.
ix) Article 144 of the Bill to Congress excepted the amount of UR 8,000,000 from the restrictions of articles 138 and 139 to fulfill previous commitments with the Housing Ministry. Article 8 of the new law enacts this exception, stating the amount inUI instead of UR,and adds the conversion of real estate already inthe balance sheet to mortgage credits, which i s only a change in assets and not new credit. This i s in line with the purpose of the bank statedin article 1.
4 Article 145 of the Billto Congress requiredthe derogation of Article 447 of Law 16736. This recommendation i s taken into account by Article 10 of the new law which gives payment priority to mortgage credits over subsidies granted by the Housing Ministry in case of mortgage execution.
53. Condition2. Deposits from the general public inBHU, excluding those appertaining to the ahorroprevio system, are beingphasedout as outlined inAnnex 1to the Letter of Development Policy (attachment 4). Total outstanding deposits inBHU, apart from those related to the ahorro previo system, shall be not more than US$750,000,000 equivalent at the Tranche ReleaseDate.
54. Compliancewith Condition2. The Annex of the LDP says that total deposits (excluding those of ahorroprevio) shall not exceed US$1.1billion at the end of 2002 and should decline by at least US$275 million each semester thereafter. Article 8 of Law 17523 of August 2002 requires that BHUtransfer its U S dollar deposits to BROU. Through an agreement between BHU, BROUandthe EconomicsMinistry signed inNovember 2002, all dollar deposits of BHU mentionedinLaw 17523 were transferred to BROU, i.e., faster than required. According to the December 2003 balance sheet of BHUreported to the Central Bank, total deposits from the non- financial private sector inBHU(general public) excluding ahorro previo amounted US$llO million, which i s less than the maximum of US$750 million originally required. Condition2 hasbeensatisfied.
55. Condition3. A due diligence, i.e., valuation and appraisal to determine the market value of the credit and investment portfolios of BHU, has been carried out by an entity satisfactory to the Bank.
56. Compliancewith Condition3. InDecember 2003, KPMGconcludedthe due diligence covering 63% of the loan portfolio with the non-financial private sector as of August 31, 2003. The sample covered 47% of loans which were 100% provisioned at the time. Taking into account other loans that were 100% provisioned, 73% of the loan portfolio of the non-financial private sector was covered. The appraisal exercise was based on a sample of 400 loans and the methodology to value the underlying collateral consisted inestimating the net-of-depreciation replacement value adjusted by the discount implicit injudicial auctions across the country. The  - 14-
valuation of the loan portfolio i s then obtained taking into account residual debt, guarantees and provisions.
57. A due diligence of promises to sell real estate--promitentes compradores--the most important asset inthe investment portfolio of BHUwas commissioned to Villamide, S.A. and finalized on September 24,2004. The valuation was basedon the estimated net discounted cash-flow of promitentes compradores obligations adjusted for historic performance of these obligations and netting out maintenance costs. To assess the extent to which the net present value of the contract i s below the value of the underlying property--andthereby ensure that incentives to pay are positive--theconsultingfirm conducted valuations of 180properties in the investment portfolio. For this purpose, the market price of sales of properties belonging to promitentescompradores was taken into account. Other assets inthe investment portfolio include buildings under construction (originating inpast commitments) which are valued at historic cost. Condition3 hasbeensatisfied.
58. Condition4. A divestment plan (including semi-annual targets for non-performing credit portfolio, foreclosed assets, real estate for sale, andpromitentescompradores in arrears) has been approved by the Board of Directors of BHU.BHUhas complied with the targets of as many calendar (i.e., January through June and/or July through December) semesters (with a minimum of one semester) as have transpired between the approval of said divestment plan and the Tranche ReleaseDate.
59. Compliancewith Condition4. BHU's Board approved a divestment plan in January 2003 referredto as "Plan Estradgico de Gestidn de Morosidad". The plan envisaged an increase in revenues as follows: (i) the first half of 2003, an increase inthe average monthly revenue during of US$2 million, of which mortgage loans US$1.5 million andpromitentes compradores US$0.5 million; and (ii) an increase inthe average monthly revenue duringthe second half of about US$l million, of which mortgage loans US$750 thousand andpromitentes compradores US$250 thousand. The plan details an extensive set of concrete actions to achieve these objectives. Based on data providedby the authorities, between December 2002 and March-June 2003, average monthly payments rose by US$1.9 million and between March-June 2003 and July- December 2003 by US$1 million. The figures respectively were US$1.5 million and US$0.6 million for mortgage loans and US$300 thousand and US$400 thousand for promitentes compradores. Thus, the targets set in the plan were nearly met between December 2002 and March-June2003 (US$1.9 million out of a plannedUS$2 million), and fully met between March-June2003 and July-December 2003 (US$1 million out of a planned US$1million).
60. InJanuary 2004, BHUsubmitted a divestment plan for 2004 which also provides for six monthly targets and achievements during2003 of real estate for sale (free and rehabilitated property), number of refinancedloans, loan cancellations, real estate sales topromitentes compradores, and number of court cases for repossession of property. All targets were met in excess except for free real estate for sale (3.5% below target) duringthe second semester, and refinancedloans for the first semester (1.4% below target) and second semester (2.8% below target).  - 15 -
61. The total number of BHU's non-performing (over 3 months of non-payment) loans and promitentes compradores rose from 27.2% inJanuary 2002 to 38.3% inMarch 2003 and then declined to 35.8% by December 2003.
62. In summary, most targets set inthe divestment plans have been met inexcess and the rest with differences of the order of 1-5% which i s deemed insignificant in the overall picture and within the parameters set inthe specific condition, Condition 4 hasbeensatisfied.
63. Condition5. The Board of Directors of BHUhas approved a new BHUcredit manual.
64. Compliancewith Condition5. BHU's Board approved a new Credit Manual inJune 2003, enacted by O/S 10306. The manual includes the stipulation that loans should be for residential property as stated inthe new Charter, and details procedures for evaluating loan applicants considering verifiable payment capacity and proven compliance history with BHUand other institutions. Moreover, the manual stipulates loan-to-values of 70% which are in line with internationalpractice (higher LTVs are usedfor assets currently on BHU's balance sheet indicatingpriority given to divestment and a probable overvaluation of these assets) and installment-to-income ratios reflecting normal banlung practices. Reflecting the credit restraint policy of BHU, the manual gives priority to clients with deposits inthe bank (ahorroprevio) and to the sale of buildings currently on Bank's balance sheet. Condition 5 hasbeensatisfied.
65. Condition6. An integrated information system for BHU's asset and liability management i s beingimplemented.
66. Compliancewith Condition6. The first concrete plan to restructure BHUand to implement a new information system date from early 2003 - soon after the Government was able to pass all the necessary legislation to change BHU's Charter through Congress (December, 2002). However, it was only after a new - and more pro-reform-boardtook over in October 2003 that a well-designed restructuringplan - agreeable to the World Bank - and a proper specification of the requiredintegrated information system was defined. InNovember 2003, BHU's management presentedterms of reference for the acquisition of an "Integrated System for Bank Management" including its technical requirements as well as provisions for maintenance, training, documentation, and the overall implementationprocess. To help finance the new system, inDecember 2003, the Uruguayan Government requested an amendment to the Technical Assistance Loan (TAL) 45980-UR to include the provision of this system within the project development objectives, estimating a total cost of US$1.7 million. The TAL was amended in May, 2004 to permit financing of public financial institutions. After Bank staff agreed on the terms of reference for the information system, an international bidding to provide and implement the new system was launched with a deadline of October 4, 2004 for receiving all bids.BHLJ'smanagement estimates that the selection of the provider and signature of contract will be completed inOctober, while a ten-phase implementation stage including tests and training will require an additional eight months.
67. Inparallel, BHUhas initiated a series of activities on the information technology front, such as digitalization of signatures, network security, and data entry that are useful to set the ground for an integrated information system but cannot be considered part of its implementation.  - 16-
68. Although BHUmanagement has initiated satisfactory steps towards the acquisition of an integrated management information system, this system i s not considered technically to be under implementation before the ten-phase implementation stage including tests and training i s substantially advanced. Thus, compliance with condition 6 has not yet been achieved. The authorities' request for a waiver is recommended in view of the steps already taken to finance and acquire the system, and the commitment of BHU's management to complete the overall implementation process incollaboration with the World Bank through the TAL. Progress inthe implementation of the new information system i s considered critical by BHU's management, especially for timely compliance with central bank informationalrequirements and for integrating BHU's databases and thereby helping to further systematize the processesof loan collection and mortgage securitization.
69. Condition 7. A restructuring plan-approved through, inter alia, resolutions ("Actas") 13770, 13775, 13779, 13786, 13789 and 13790 of the Board of Directors of BHU (including the appointment and accession of professional management, creation of new loan recovery and finance departments, and a substantial downsizing of BHU) i s beingimplementedas set forth in such resolutions.
70. Compliance with Condition 7. The resolutions mentioned above indicate changes in interest rates, creation of collection and cost reduction teams, reductionin operating costs, '
approval of financial projections, issuance of bonds, suspension of overtime payments, suspension of charitable donations, nomination of new Accounting and InspectionManagers, and creation of Human Resources and Finance areas. Several internal orders (6rdenes de servicio) have implementedthese resolutions: O/S 1019l,O/S 10195,0/S 10202, while new resolutions have complemented the restructuring process: 13840, 13846, 13855, 13875, 13884, 13891, 13893, 13895 and 13899. The latter have definedchanges inretirement age, specified incentives to early retirement, created a Social Housing Area, created a Trust FundArea, redefinedthe overall organizational structure separating business functions (Social Housing, Commercial Loan Recovery, Credit Origination and Finance) and support functions, defined an evaluation process for the nomination and appointment of management, and consolidated initiatives into an overall Restructuring Plan.
71. The consolidated Restructuring Planincluded in resolution 13891of December 2003 was prepared with the support of the Bank and the final version was reviewed by Bank staff. The new organizational structure for BHUresponds to the objectives of the Program. It includes the appointment of professional management in key positions and the definition of a transparent, competitive and objective nomination process. Interms of downsizing, total BHUpersonnel decreasedby 28% during the last two calendar years, from 1384 employees inDecember 2001 to 998 full time employees by December 2003. The reduction i s 45% if the 233 employees working at the HousingMinistry (MVOTMA) are excluded. Inparallel, personnel expenses decreasedby 52%, from US$48.9 million to US$23.5 million duringthis period, while overall operating costs decreasedby 35%.
72. Bank staff have assessed through on-site visits that the change inmanagement processes and attitudes implicit inthe Restructuring Plan have actually been established. All key managers  - 17-
were interviewed (President, Vice-president, Loan Recovery, Credit Origination, Finance, Social Housing, Accounting and Administration, Human Resources, and Strategy and Organization) with satisfactory results. Condition 7 hasbeensatisfied.
73. Condition8. A bill removing existing differences between BCU's supervision powers over state owned and private banks, including powers of B C Uto impose fines on state owned banks, presented by the Executive to Congress on September, 20 2001 has been enacted, regulated and i s beingimplemented. When enacted, said bill shall also prescribe B C Uto inform the Executive about said fines for the Executive to consider imposing sanctions on the members of the Board of Directors of said state ownedbanks, as regulatedby article 197 of the Borrower's Constitution.
74. Compliancewith Condition8. Law 17613 was enactedinDecember 2002. Inarticle 6, paragraph 3, the law explicitly revises Decree Law 15322 and Law 16237 to authorize B C Uto observe, sanction and impose fines on state-owned institutions. Paragraph 2 of the same article prescribes B C Uto inform the Executive about non-compliance with regulations by these institutions and the consequent resolutions andfines for the Executive to consider imposing rectifications or sanctions on Board members according to article 197 of the Uruguayan Constitution.
75. The Law didnot require a special regulation other that the Boards of BROU and BHUhave been notified. The Superintendence of Financial Institutions at B C Uevaluates public banks on a regularbasis and has already imposedfines as permittedby the new law. Condition8 hasbeen satisfied.

doc.repnme: Uruguay - Structural Adjustment Loan (SAL) and Special Structural Adjustment Loan Project : release of the second tranche and waiver of two conditions
doc.abstracts: The objectives of the Structural Adjustment Loan (SAL) and Special Structural Adjustment Loan (SSAL) at the time o f the acute banking and economic crisis in July 2002 were to contribute to fiscal adjustment, reform the National Mortgage Bank (BHU), protect social programs, improve the efficiency of social expenditures and reform the unemployment insurance regime. The program was part of a concerted effort with the International Monetary Fund (IMF) and the Inter-American Development Bank (IADB) to support Uruguay's efforts to withstand the impact o f strong external shocks, address domestic weaknesses and set the stage for sustainable growth over the medium and long term. As a result of tight fiscal, monetary and financial sector policies and reforms, Uruguay was able to reverse the downward trend in bank deposits, freely float its exchange rate without jeopardizing price stability, and reduce sovereign risk premia to manageable levels. After contracting sharply in 2002, the economy recovered in 2003 and is projected to grow at least 9% in 2004. In view of the overall performance, progress with the implementation of the program as described in the Letter of Development Policy, and compliance with most of the specific conditions agreed in Schedule 3 to the Loan Agreements, the granting of two waivers (out of 18 conditions) as requested by the Borrower is recommended on a no-objection basis for release of the second tranche of the Loans 7137 and 7138. The basis for the evaluation of Borrower performance and the recommended waivers is set forth in this report.
